data.title: What are Domain Extensions? List of Domain Extensions in 2024
data.meta_description: Discover the full list of domain extensions in 2024, the biggest TLDs, types of top level domains, and the impact of extensions on your site.
data.text:
The Internet Assigned Numbers Authority‚Äôs (IANA‚Äôs) official list of domain extensions has around 2,000 options as of the time of this writing.

The sheer size of this list can make the prospect of choosing a domain extension overwhelming, but the choice becomes easier when you understand what these extensions actually mean.

üëâ So, in this guide, we‚Äôll explain everything you need to know about domain extensions:

What they are

What they mean for your website

Types and list of domain extensions

The three most common domain extensions

Let‚Äôs get started!

What are domain extensions?

Domain extensions, or top-level domains (TLDs), are the suffixes that follow the last dot in a website‚Äôs domain name. Examples include .com, .org, or .net. These TLDs serve as online identifiers, classifying websites according to their organization type, location, and purpose.

History of domain extensions

The history of domain extensions can be traced as far back as the 1980s, when the IANA kicked off with six domain extensions. Each of them represented a different type of organization.

There was:

.com, which stands for ‚Äúcommercial‚Äù

.org, which stands for ‚Äúorganization‚Äù

.gov, which stands for ‚Äúgovernment‚Äù

.mil, which stands for ‚Äúmilitary‚Äù

.edu, which stands for ‚Äúeducation‚Äù

They were soon joined by country code TLDs, which started rolling out in the 1990s. Their role was to represent different countries and territories using determiners like:

.jp for ‚ÄúJapan‚Äù

.de for ‚ÄúGermany‚Äù

.uk for the ‚ÄúUnited Kingdom‚Äù

.us for the ‚ÄúUnited States‚Äù

Then in the early 2000s, the list of domain extensions expanded further to provide options for other types of industries, interests, and communities:

.info, which represents ‚Äúinformation‚Äù

.pro, which stands for ‚Äúprofessional‚Äù

.biz, which is short for ‚Äúbusiness‚Äù

But, it was not until 2012 that ICANN made drastic changes to its domain extension registry, allowing anyone with a large enough budget to create custom top-level domains [1]. That was the beginning of the rise of branded TLDs like .bmw, .google, .sky, etc.

What do domain extensions mean for your website?

Purpose üéØ

Initially, the aim of domain extensions was to categorize websites based on their type or purpose.

For instance, websites ending in .com were meant to be commercial, while .org was typically chosen by nonprofit organizations to distinguish themselves from educational or governmental entities.

.co and .biz, on the other hand, have gained recognition as appropriate domain extensions for online business sites, whereas .info is often adopted by informational sites like research platforms.

Location üìç

Code top-level domains (ccTLDs) ‚Äì like ‚Äú.us‚Äù for the United States and ‚Äú.uk‚Äù for the United Kingdom exist to associate brands with a specific country or region.

Branding üçé

The choice of domain extension can influence your brand identity, brand recall, localization, and brand protection.

For example, when it comes to reinforcing brand recall, you want to choose a memorable domain extension that helps your brand stand out above its competitors.

A .com extension meets this need, because it happens to be the most memorable domain extension. Consumers give it a memorability score of 44% [2]. Another great performer is .co, which ranks second with a score of 33%.

Types and list of domain extensions

On IANA‚Äôs database, you‚Äôll find all the domain extensions classified into three primary types:

Country-code top-level domain (ccTLD)

Sponsored top-level domains (sTLDs)

Generic top-level domains (gTLDs)

Here are their details‚Ä¶ üïµÔ∏è

#1. Country-code top-level domains (ccTLDs)

Country-code top-level domains (ccTLDs) are designed to cater to specific countries, sovereign states, and territories. They usually come in two initials drawn from the Latin alphabet.

You won‚Äôt be able to register random ccTLD extensions, though. Many of them have geographical restrictions that require you to be a resident of the host country, territory, or sovereign state.

These domain extensions are typically controlled from within the host country by government agencies or non-profit organizations.

Here‚Äôs a quick list of domain extensions for specific countries:

.za ‚Äì South Africa

.us ‚Äì United States

.uk ‚Äì United Kingdom

.sa ‚Äì Saudi Arabia

#2. Sponsored top-level domains (sTLDs)

These domain extensions are associated with a specific community or group, which is represented by a sponsor. You‚Äôll notice that they‚Äôre not available for public use like their generic top-level domains (gTLDs) counterparts. Instead, sTLDs are restricted to specific niches or industries.

Take, for instance, sponsored top-level domains like .gov and .edu. The former is strictly reserved for government bodies in the US, whereas the latter is exclusively meant for educational institutions.

Other examples of sTLD domain extensions include:

.int ‚Äì sponsored by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) for international organizations

.gov ‚Äì sponsored by the General Services Administration (GSA) for U.S. government agencies

.edu ‚Äì sponsored by EduCause for accredited degree-granting institutions

#3. Generic top-level domains (gTLDs)

Generic top-level domains, commonly known as gTLDs, are versatile domain extensions that are not limited by regional affiliations or country codes. Unlike country-specific domains, they do not require a representative and can be possessed by anyone, regardless of location or background.

There are two types of gTLDs:

Restricted ‚Äì These domain extensions are reserved for accredited businesses, professionals, or individuals with special qualifications. Examples of restricted gTLDs include .biz, .name, and .pro.

Unrestricted ‚Äì Unrestricted gTLDs are open for registration by anyone, without any restrictions on acquisition. Some of the most popular unrestricted gTLDs include .com, .net, .org, and .info.

Three most common domain extensions

Out of the roughly 2,000 domain extensions in IANA‚Äôs database, the most popular ones (excluding country-code TLDs) are:

.com

.org

.net

.com

The .com domain is the most widely recognized and commonly used option for websites, making it the default choice for many individuals, businesses, and organizations.

It was originally intended for commercial entities. However, over time it has grown to become the primary top-level domain option across the board, and by a wide margin. As of the time of this writing, it has a market share of about 52.8% of all the registered domains globally, [3] and the gap between .com and the second most popular domain extension, .org, is staggering.

This dominance, however, means you might struggle to find an appropriate domain name using this extension. Find out more by reading our in-depth guide to the .com domain extension.

.org

The .org gTLD, which holds a market share of 4.4%, is the second most popular domain extension.

.org here stands for ‚Äúorganization‚Äù, as the extension was originally meant for non-profit organizations. However, this requirement was only enforced temporarily, after which it was indefinitely suspended by ICANN.

The generic top-level domain is now open for use by all types of entities.

.net

.net is the other option that you might be looking into ‚Äì as it‚Äôs the fourth most popular domain extension, with a market share of 3.1%.

It has its origins in the term ‚Äúnetwork‚Äù, and that‚Äôs because the domain extension was initially designated for organizations in the networking technologies space.

The restrictions on its usage were never strictly enforced, though. And so, over time, .net evolved into a ‚Äúgeneral purpose namespace‚Äù, which now serves as a viable alternative to .com domains.

Finding the best domain extension for your site

You can, of course, dig through IANA‚Äôs list of domain extensions for ideas.
